titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: We had fixed on to-morrow as the day of our departure upon our return to Quincy, but my wife was so unwell in the former part of this day that it was doubtful whether we should not be under the necessity of postponing our movement, one or more days— Towards evening however she so far recovered her strength and Spirits that she concluded to proceed in the morning— We were all intently occupied and none more so than Mrs. Adams, in packing up, settling accounts and bills, and getting ready to go at six O’Clock to-morrow. Mary has concluded to go, and take her daughter Mary-Louisa, with us. As the order of the Treasurer of the United States in favour of myself as Attorney to Ebenezer Lobdell, promised me by the Secretary of the Treasury, to be forthcoming yesterday was not yet in hand, I called this day noon at his Office and received it from him— It was drawn on the Collector of the Customs at Boston, instead of the new Receiver General Isaac Hill, as I had requested and he had promised— He now said that Mr Hill had not yet quite completed his arrangements for entering upon the execution of his office— I asked him what was the present condition of the Smithsonian funds invested in bonds of the State of Arkansaw.— He said the interest upon the bonds had been hitherto punctually paid, and he was just now receiving proposals for a new investment of the interest of the last half year—and he read to me several Letters containing these proposals.— They were of the States of New-York and others at 5. per Cent a year, and at about 90 per Cent, and of Kentucky and Arkansaw at 6 per Cent interest—the Kentucky bonds at 90 per Cent, and those of Arkansaw at 70. He said he should take the lowest bid. I expressed my strong disapprobation of the Sale by the Secretary of the Navy of Stocks of the States, at a much lower price than he had purchased them at— He said there had never been any sale of the Stocks of the States by the Department of the Treasury.— Besides the struggle to redeem the arrears of my Diary which accrued unavoidably in the last fortnight of the Session, I answered and declined the invitation of Mr A. J. Downing to visit his Botanical Garden, and Nursery at Newburgh opposite Mr de Wint’s— My wife visited this evening her brother Mr Thomas B. Johnson, who has been very sick, but is convalescent. Mrs W. S. Smith left us this day, and removed to Mr Frye’s. My neighbour Mr Parris, and Mr Cutts and his daughter visited us this Evening; and Mr John Bell of Tennessee, with whom I had a long conversation, upon the prospects of the Presidential Election— We agreed that the present appearances were favourable, though by no means certain for a change; but I asked Mr Bell, what were the expectations beyond the change, and found him quite unprepared to answer— He knew not who would compose the Cabinet of Genl. Harrison, and was not disposed to bestow much confidence in advance upon whoever it might be— I told him that at all Events he must be the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and he confessed that it would be the summit of his ambition— I was up packing till near midnight— Dismissed Thomas with a warm recommendation—
From Washington through Baltimore to Philadelphia.

At six this morning, with my wife, my deceased son John’s widow, and her daughter Mary Louisa, and Jeremy Leary and Mary Flinn a waiting man and woman, natives of Ireland I took the Rail-road Cars from Washington to Baltimore, which city we reached at half past eight— The Cars were filled as usual, but of the other passengers the only one with whom I was acquainted was Mr Joseph R. Underwood a member of the House of Representatives from Kentucky; who left our company at the viaduct house seven miles short of Baltimore— He is returning home and was to join company with Mr John Pope on the road to Frederick this day— After waiting one hour at Baltimore we started in the Railway Cars for Philadelphia—crossed the causway between two waters 24 miles from Baltimore, and the Susquehanna river at Havre de Grace 36 miles from Baltimore—snatched a scramble dinner, the Ladies not alighting from the Cars at Wilmington Delaware 36 miles from Philadelphia, and reached Grays ferry nearly an hour before the Cars from Philadelphia, for Baltimore came out to meet us.— The Horses which took them out took us in and at 4. P.M. we alighted at the depot in Market Street— Here was bustle and confusion, but we found good lodgings at the Union Hotel in Chesnut Street, now kept by Mr Jones, who was formerly the bar keeper at the United States Hotel— Many of the passengers from Baltimore, proceeded immediately in another line of Cars to New-York— The distance between that City and Washington being now regularly one day’s journey— We met in the drawing room at Jones’s, Mrs Williams, daughter of the late William Pinkney of Baltimore, in deep mourning, and on her return alone from the North where she has been with her sick husband— She has so much changed since I had last seen her that I did not know her till she recognized me and named herself to me— Towards evening I walked out and called at Mr John Sergeant’s. At his door, as I rung the bell I met his third daughter Sarah, with Mr Henry A. Wise to whom she is engaged to be married— They were walking out together, and as soon as she had ascertained that her father and mother were both gone out, I hastened to take leave, conscious of being quite a supernumerary in that company. In the evening Mr and Mrs Sergeant called upon us at our lodgings, but my wife and Mrs John Adams had both gone to bed. Mr John Connell likewise paid me a visit, and I had conversation with him respecting the Bank of the United States and Mr Nicholas Biddle— It has been recently charged that he is indebted to the Bank far beyond his means of solvency; and the stock of the bank has within a few days fallen from 73 to 61— Connell says that the charge is false and that Mr Biddle owes nothing to the Bank— I suppose he means on his own account. There is a heavy debt due from the late Cashier Mr Cowperthwait. Connell says he believes it is all secured? Oh! quantum est in rebus inane! I saw this Evening also Mr and Mrs David Sears of Boston, and Mrs Aylwin, the daughter of John Langdon.
From Philadelphia to New-York. Long-Island Sound.

This morning we left our lodgings at the Union Hotel, and at 7. O’Clock departed in the Steamer, for Bordentown; and thence proceeded in the Cars to South Amboy; and thence in the Steamer Independence to New-York—as we were drawing up to the wharf, a man was leaning against the slight railing round the bow of the boat—the railing gave way and the man was precipitated into the river—before the alarm could be given he was far astern of the Steamer, and apparently could not swim; she was immediately backed to endeavour to save him, and the aid of several small boats plying in the vicinity of the spot was called and given, but before he could be reached he went down and was ushered into eternity— The steamer went in to the side and I gave no sign of feeling more than others, but the heart knew its own bitterness.

At the same wharf where the Independence landed at 3. in the afternoon was lying the Steamer Massachusetts to depart at 5 for Stonington and Providence— I merely crossed the wharf from one boat to the other, and went not in to the City at all— My wife and Mrs John Adams took a stroll, and returned— At 5. P.M we parted from the wharf, and the first operation of the Steamer was to run down and swamp a small row boat in which were three men, who in an instant found themselves floating in deep waters, to struggle for their lives. They were however all saved, and we made no stay to apologize for the cold bath into which we had plunged them— I met some old acquaintance and made some new ones in the course of this day— Among the morning passengers from Philadelphia was Dr Moore, some time Director of the United States Mint in that City, and Mr Wharton a Lawyer of some standing— Mr James Fisher said to be 86 years of age, who accosted me, and told me that the first time he saw me was at the house of Mr Joshua Johnson on Tower Hill at London in 1796 or 1797— He introduced me now to Mrs Fisher, his wife and said they were going on a visit to Mr John Alsop King on Long-Island—his son, Dr Charles King having married a grand daughter of Mr Fisher— We had also as Messmate passengers Dr and Mrs John Warren of Boston, and Mrs Crowninshield daughter of David Sears, and wife of B. W. Crowninshield’s son. Dr Warren has been to Philadelphia, to testify in a trial upon habeas corpus, for the possession of an infant between a young Genevan named d’Hauteville, and his wife a daughter of Mr Sears—a Marriage of disappointed ambition made by the mother under a delusive belief that d’Hauteville was a Count, when her daughter was with her in her late European tour. When they found that he was a mere plebeian his wife deserted him, returned to her mother, and came back with her from Europe— Meanwhile this child, a son was born; and she has kept him in her charge— But d’Hauteville has followed them from Europe, demanding first his wife; but upon finding her reluctant, waiving that claim and insisting only upon his paternal right to the child— There has been much extra-judicial negotiation, and much litigation in state tribunals in the case which is now under advisement upon a habeas corpus before a judge at Philadelphia— I took two State Rooms in the Massachusetts and we cleaved the waters of Long-Island Sound, through a smooth sea a light eastern breeze, and a dark Evening till I turned in at 10 p.m.
